The framework does not do anything to help you set up test data beyond
calling setUp() before each test
and tearDown() afterwards. What you do after that is your own business.
Usually it takes many test methods to sufficiently test a method in your
actual code -- each one testing to make sure that a particular behavior of
your method is working properly given a set of inputs.

For example, if I have a method named setFoo(Object bar) then it is not
unusual for me to write at least two methods for this function: testSetFoo()
and testSetFooWithNull(). If a collection is involved, it is very common to
have a test case for an empty collection, a collection with a single item, a
collection with a few items, and a null collection. 

Hope this helps,
-Chris

-----Original Message-----
From: kelly, Burrowa [mailto:hello1790@...]

Hi!

For each method in my class there is a testMethod
in the JUnit TestCase class. Can somebody throw light
on how to run the Test for different input cases?

thanks!
